Abstract  
Relaxor behaviour in a thin film of partially ordered PbSc0.5Ta0.5O3 (PST) was confirmed via 
slim P-E loops and the frequency dependence of the temperature at which the dielectric constant 
is maximum. Indirect measurements of the electrocaloric effect suggest that removing a field of 
774 kV cm
-1
 yields a temperature change of -3.5ºC to -6.9ºC over a broad range of operating 
temperatures near room temperature (1 ºC-127 ºC), with a correspondingly large refrigerant 
capacity of 662 J kg
-1
. In addition to low electrical hysteresis, there is negligible thermal 
hysteresis. PST thin films are therefore promising for EC cooling near room temperature.  
 
Introduction 
Electrocaloric (EC) coolers have stimulated great attention since the recent discovery of the giant 
EC effect in ferroelectric thin films [1-2]. This has sparked the desire to develop an 
environmentally friendly, powerful and low-cost EC refrigerator [3-7]. The EC effect is typically 
characterized by the entropy change, ∆S, driven by the application/removal of an electric field, E, 
associated with a temperature change, ∆T as follows:

where P is polarization, c is specific heat capacity, ρ is density and E1 and E2 are the starting and 
final applied fields, respectively.  These equations are not straightforward to apply if there is 
electrical or thermal hysteresis, e.g. near first-order phase transitions or within the “glassy” non-
ergodic state of some relaxors [5]. 
Lead scandium tantalate, PbSc0.5Ta0.5O3 (PST), has a perovskite structure, A(B'B'')O3, in 
which B-site disorder leads to relaxor behaviour. Appropriate heat treatments promote B-site 
ordering, and so long-range ferroelectric order may be observed [8-10]. Relaxor PST undergoes 
a diffuse second-order phase transition whereas a first-order phase transition is found in highly 
ordered PST [8-10]. While a paraelectric (or relaxor)-ferroelectric phase transition is known to 
occur between 0 ºC and room temperature depending on the degree of PST ordering [8,10], 
dielectric measurements of PST thin films have indicated the existence of several anomalies at 
cryogenic temperatures [11]. The underlying mechanisms are unresolved but could involve 
structural phase transitions and domain-wall dynamics. Here we investigate the EC effect in a 
partially ordered PbSc0.5Ta0.5O3 thin film, which is expected to exhibit a high pyroelectric 
coefficient, a phase transition near room temperature and slim relaxor-like P-E loops [12-15]. 
Furthermore, PST compositions with  < 0.82 [8] have demonstrated a second-order phase 
transition and so no thermal hysteresis is expected. 
 
Experimental 
A partially ordered PbSc0.5Ta0.5O3 thin film was fabricated by sol-gel using precursors of lead 
acetate trihydrate Pb(OAc)2.3H2O, scandium acetate (Sc(OAc)3, and tantalum ethoxide 
Ta(OEt)5. The scandium acetate and tantalum ethoxide were mixed together, dissolved in 2-
methoxyethanol (2ME) and refluxed for 10 hrs. Separately, lead acetate trihydrate was dissolved 
in 2ME, and the water was distilled out of the system. Both solutions were mixed and stirred at 
room temperature for 2 hrs. The final concentration of the synthesized PST sol was 0.3M. PST 
sol was spin-coated at 3000 rpm for 30 sec onto a Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate. Each layer was

pyrolized at 350 ºC for 1 min. After the deposition of 5 layers, the film was annealed at 650 ºC 
via Rapid Thermal Annealing with a heating ramp of 18 ºC/sec. The thickness of each layer was 
20 nm, and the above-mentioned process was repeated ten times to obtain the desired 200 nm.

constant measurements were carried out using a Wayne-Kerr impedance analyzer (Wayne Kerr 
Electronics, UK). P-E loops were obtained by means of a Radiant Technologies RT66A 
ferroelectric tester (Radiant Technologies Inc., USA). A Peltier element was used for 
temperature control.

The temperature dependences of the dielectric constant, , and loss tangent, tan , at 
different frequencies are illustrated in Fig. 3. Dielectric constant and loss tangent show maxima 
at Tm near room temperature, and the strong frequency dependence indicates a relaxor-
ferroelectric phase transition. The similarity in Tdd  below and above Tm confirms a second-
order phase transition. The values of  in our PST thin film are smaller than those in previously 
reported partially ordered PST thin films (between 1000-6000) which were annealed at T > 
700 ºC [10]. This may be due to the use of a lower annealing temperature here (650 ºC), resulting 
in a smaller average grain size.  
In order to evaluate the EC effect in the PST thin film, P-E loops at 1 kHz were measured 
at different temperatures, as shown in Fig. 4. In addition to the frequency dependence of Tm 
(Fig. 3), the slim P-E loops corroborate previously reported relaxor behaviour of partially 
ordered PST thin films [10]. The temperature dependence of the polarization at different fields, 
established from the upper branches of the hysteresis loops in E > 0 upon cooling  and heating , 
is presented in Fig. 5. The PST thin film exhibits negligible thermal hysteresis. Given that we are

The maximum hysteresis loss, determined from P-E loop area for E > 0 at 9 ºC, could at most

reasonable estimate for our relaxor films. The fact that, the estimated RC value in PST thin film 
is much higher than that in magnetocaloric Gd-based materials (360 J kg

electrocaloric PST thin films may be used as a media in a cost-efficient refrigeration system 
operating near room temperature. 
 Conclusions 
A relaxor thin film of PbSc0.5Ta0.5O3 with partial B-site order (Ω = 0.32) was fabricated by sol-
gel, and subjected to rapid thermal annealing. Its relaxor nature near room temperature was 
confirmed by slim loops and the frequency dependence of Tm. PST thin films could be promising 
for EC refrigeration, as they combine a set of remarkable properties: 1) a large EC effect below 
and above room temperature of ∆S ~ -5 J K-1 kg-1 for under 774 kV cm-1, 2) no thermal 
NPL Management Ltd - Internal 
hysteresis, 3) low electrical losses of 4.8% and 4) a small variation of ∆S within 1 ºC -127 ºC 
which yields a large RC = 662 J kg
-1
 for ∆E = 774 kV cm-1.
